Award.AwardTitle: SEP: Collaborative: Achieving a Sustainable Energy Pathway for Wind Turbine Blade Manufacturing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The NSF Sustainable Energy pathways (SEP) Program, under the umbrella of the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability (SEES) initiative, will support the research program of Prof. Christopher Niezrecki and co-workers at the University of Massachusetts, Lowell, and Prof. Janet Twomey and co-workers at Wichita State University. The objective of this highly multidisciplinary study is the preparation of new forms of bio-derived materials for next generation wind turbine blades. These blades will be designed with the mechanical performance, economic viability, and environmental life cycle to enable sustainable wind energy pathways. Past research on biobased polymers has focused on thermoplastics that do not have the creep resistance and other properties necessary for significant structural applications. This project will focus on thermoset epoxies that are only a single reaction step from vegetable oil (a consistent, readily available feedstock), thus minimizing energy use and cost. Additionally, by developing an understanding of molecular-level thermal reworkability in composites through the inclusion of an appropriate catalyst, this work will enable a new end-of-life paradigm. Scaled test structures with mechanical and dynamic features comparable to utility-scale wind turbine blades will be constructed and their performance evaluated. Using these results new materials will be able to be quickly assessed without full scale tests. An environmental life cycle impact analysis will highlight areas for improved sustainability in the design of the biomaterials and end-of-life options for blades. An economic evaluation along with life cycle cost and toxic use analyses will provide a comparative economic evaluation of bio-derived alternatives to traditional petroleum-based thermosets along with the impact of converting to bio-based wind turbine manufacturing on job creation, education, and skills requirements.

With an expectation of growth in the U.S. to 170,000 turbines in 2030, wind energy represents a renewable resource to address 20% of the U.S. energy demand. From a systems point of view, this growth creates a need to dispose of well over 34,000 blades/year (each as large as 62 m long and weighing 18 tons) in the U.S. and approximately five times as many globally. Presently, nearly all of these blades are manufactured from glass fiber composites containing large amounts of petroleum-based epoxy resins and at their end of life they are very difficult to recycle. Spent blades are either land-filled, burned to extract heat for co-generation of electricity, or cut up and used as filler in construction. This project will determine how to effectively replace existing petroleum-based epoxy resins with bio-based materials that are reworkable so that they can be repaired and/or their materials can be reused at the end-of-life. Concurrently the impacts of the new blades on the economy, wind industry, environment, and society will be studied. Both graduate and undergraduate students will be exposed to technical and nontechnical problems important to industry, and a strong outreach effort will be implemented using demonstrations to motivate the interest of women and K-12 students in science and engineering. Wind Energy Research Workshops will be organized to serve a national audience of industry participants, scientists, and engineers.

This project will develop a transformative approach to the manufacturing of composites in general and wind turbine blades in particular. This work will lead to composite manufacturing that is more sustainable and less reliant on petroleum-based resins while enabling effective composite repair and recycling. The research will impact not only the wind industry, but many other areas of composite usage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary research objective of this project was the development and evaluation of new forms of bio-derived materials for next generation wind turbine blades (as well as other composite products), with the mechanical performance, economic viability, and environmental life cycle to enable sustainable wind energy pathways. With an expectation of growth in the U.S. to 170,000 turbines in 2030, wind energy represents a renewable resource to address 20% of the U.S. energy demand. From a systems point of view, this growth also creates a need to dispose of well over 34,000 blades/year (each as large as ~60 m long and weighing 18 tons) in the U.S. and approximately five times as many globally. Essentially all of these blades are manufactured from glass fiber composites containing large amounts of petroleum-based epoxy resins, and at their end of life, they are very difficult to recycle. Spent blades are either land-filled, burned to extract heat for co-generation of electricity, or cut up and used as filler in construction. This project was concerned with understanding how to effectively replace existing petroleum-based epoxy resins with bio-based materials and to understand of how to recover the fiber-reinforced thermoset composites for reuse at the end of the product lifecycle.  Through life-cycle analysis the project also gained an understanding of how the new materials impact blade manufacturing cost, the environment, and society.

 

The efforts have focused on thermoset epoxies that are only a single reaction step from vegetable oil (a more consistent, readily available feedstock), thus minimizing energy intensity and cost.  In support of such efforts, scaled test structures (I-beams) with mechanical and dynamic features comparable to utility-scale wind turbine blades were created and their performance validated.  The size-scaling technique provided a means to assess new materials in lieu of full-scale tests. A series of beams at different length scales (small, medium, and large) were constructed and modeled to demonstrate similarity.  A number of beams made from conventional resin were compared to a set of beams made from the new bio-resin by using static and fatigue mechanical testing.  The results indicated that the bio-material was slightly less stiff compared to a beam made from conventional resin.  The team was able to demonstrate reworkability in which the material had the ability to go from a rigid epoxy plate, then after heating the plate was deformed, cooled down, and then it retained the new shape.  Likewise, the team showed that we could form a bio-based epoxy resin, grind it up, compression mold it, and re-form a new part from the recycled resin.  The researchers also showed that it was possible to take a composite, and after chemical recycling of the resin, recover the fiber reinforcement undamaged, and use it again in a new composite.  In tandem, an environmental life-cycle analysis was performed to gain an understanding of how the new resin system impacts manufacturing cost and impacts resources. We conducted a life cycle cost (LCC) analysis comparing two manufacturing processes of a 55-meter wind turbine blade: one was the conventional process, which utilizes petroleum-based epoxy resin for the matrix of the composite material in the shells of the blades. The other was a prototype bio-based process that utilizes epoxidized linseed oil (ELO) instead of conventional epoxy resin.  Our results suggest that the conventional, petroleum-based system is more cost-effective than the prototype bio-based manufacturing process, from both private and social perspectives. Results are mainly driven by the elevated cost of equipment and consumables needed to handle higher curing temperatures in the prototype bio-based system.  At the same time, this analysis highlights the potential of the bio-based system if a means can be found to reduce the elevated cure temperatures it requires, providing useful guidance for future research in this area.

 

 

The project also included a strong outreach effort that included high school and undergraduate student presentations as well as numerous technical conference presentations.  The team also leveraged the existing service-learning infrastructure at UMass Lowell to integrate the research within classes and projects.  Numerous undergraduate and graduate students were trained and 3 students received their Ph.D. degrees to date with another about to finish.  Many conference and journal papers were written to help disseminate the findings.
